utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I think you two need to discuss this further-

utterance.speaker: Hank
utterance.content: We’ve been trying to get pregnant almost since we met.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Well, it’s your wife’s decision whether or not she-

utterance.speaker: Hank
utterance.content: She wants to trade a child for a kidney, that’s murder! I’m not gonna let her do that.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Foreman says we’ve got a problem with the transplant.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If she terminates the pregnancy, he’s not going to let himself die on principle.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: …Would you give up a baby for someone you love?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Please tell me I don’t have to decide. Depends, how long would they live?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Is this a pragmatic question for you?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Fifty years, no problem. Six months, I say let ‘em die. Well, I’ve actually given this a lot of thought, and my personal tipping point is seven years, eight months, and 14 days.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I couldn’t do it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You found religion.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Do you have to be religious to believe a fetus is a life?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: There seems to be a correlation. I’m, uh… Do you like monster trucks?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: …I don’t know what they are.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: …Right. I got two tickets. Friday night.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You asking me to go with you?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Sure. Sounds good.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Like a…date?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Exactly. Except for the “date” part. Forget it.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: No, I-I was gonna go to the oncology dinner…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: ‘Course, you have to hear Wilson’s lecture.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: No. I just found out he canceled like, two weeks ago. So… what do we wear?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Still with us, Hank?

utterance.speaker: Hank
utterance.content: Yeah. My chest feels funny…

utterance.speaker: Hank
utterance.content: Where’s Lola…?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: 10 units of insulin sub q, an IV push -

utterance.speaker: Nurse
utterance.content: It’s still dropping.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Why’s his potassium up?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Damned if I know.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We've got to suck the potassium out of him. We gotta get his heart rate down.

utterance.speaker: Nurse
utterance.content: Need a crash cart!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It’s definitely not Addison’s.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: It’s not steroids either.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: His heart rate is 130 and rising, like a Randy Johnson line drive.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: A for effort.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: There’s no point in doing the transplant. Even if he was stable enough, it’s obvious that we have no idea what’s wrong with him!

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: First it’s too high, and now it’s too low?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: His heart’s not responding to the atropine.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Heart rate’s down to 40.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I thought it was up.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Now it’s down. Last time he went out at 35.

utterance.speaker: Lola
utterance.content: What’s wrong?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I have no idea. Hit him with the atropine before he gets to 35 again.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We’ve already given him 3 ml.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Apparently, that’s not enough.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: We can’t stabilize his heart rate.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What did you do to him?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Kayexalate.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: His pulse was through the roof. So is his potassium.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: It wouldn’t do this.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: But something did. Call me when he’s stable…or dead.

utterance.speaker: Warner
utterance.content: I remember the first time. You weren’t even supposed to be pitching that day. I’d flown all the way to Tokyo to watch this kid, and he gets tossed for arguing a call in the first inning. Ah, your pitches…perfect. Ball seemed to go faster than your arm. It was like the rules didn’t apply, like physics couldn’t slow you down. Goddamn, it was beautiful.

utterance.speaker: Hank
utterance.content: Hey, Warner.

utterance.speaker: Warner
utterance.content: Hey, kid. How ya feelin’?

utterance.speaker: Hank
utterance.content: I hurt. My arm, my head…everywhere.

utterance.speaker: Warner
utterance.content: They must have dialed down the morphine. That’s just wrong, you’re in pain. Hey I got something for ya.

utterance.speaker: Hank
utterance.content: No…

utterance.speaker: Warner
utterance.content: A doc in St. Louis gave ‘em to me for a migraine.

utterance.speaker: Hank
utterance.content: I’m an addict, I-I can’t take that.

utterance.speaker: Warner
utterance.content: Even Lola was okay with the morphine. This stuff’s just a little stronger. Go on.

utterance.speaker: Hank
utterance.content: I’ll just try one, Warner.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Three more symptoms. Heart rate up, heart rate down, now he’s hallucinating.

utterance.speaker: Hank
utterance.content: …You gotta promise not to tell Lola…

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: He’s not just dreaming?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No REM. He’s actually awake.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Drugs?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not psychedelics, not with the heart symptoms.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: All hallucinations would point to digitalis. It would also mess up his heart. But, he’s not on it, and why would he take it?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: …Yeah. Pithy analysis. I can see why they asked you to speak at the cancer dinner. I’m sorry I’m gonna miss it.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I’m sorry about the monster trucks.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, I think it’s great. You’re…giving back.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: The only thing is… the digitalis…it would only explain the later symptoms, not the original ones.

utterance.speaker: Warner
utterance.content: Sure, it’s got a lotta movement, problem is everybody sees the movement. Yer throwing yer curve ball, like yer throwing a curve ball. Deception, that’s it. Same motion, less movement, so it won’t come back at ya. How’d you get in here?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Spoke Spanish. Told them I was the new shortstop from the Dominican.

utterance.speaker: Warner
utterance.content: How’s Hank doin’?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Lousy. Around your fingernails, that swelling, it’s called clubbing. Hippocrates noticed that a lot of his friends who also had that, tended to frequently grab their chests and die.

utterance.speaker: Warner
utterance.content: Yeah, I got a heart condition. What’s wrong with Hank?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What do you take for it?

utterance.speaker: Warner
utterance.content: Digitalis.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Got ‘em with you?

utterance.speaker: Warner
utterance.content: That’s weird. I just filled this prescription a couple days ago. There’s another bottle here.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Don’t bother. Hank Wiggen stole your pills. He tried to kill himself.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So what happened? He left the bottle open, while he went to get some water? Next time, just take the whole bottle.

utterance.speaker: Hank
utterance.content: Hey man, you got no right-

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: See, people remember how many they’ve got. Date’s right on the label, number of pills, regular person can do the math. But a junkie doesn’t have to. It’s how many pills he’s got left, that’s all he’s thinking about. Bought a big insurance policy?

utterance.speaker: Hank
utterance.content: This isn’t about the money.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not for you, no. Most reputable stores won’t cash your checks after you’re dead. But for Lola-well, girls like that, they’re all about the money-

utterance.speaker: Hank
utterance.content: Don’t you say that. She already saved my life. I was dead in Japan and she brought me back, everything since then, that’s gravy, it’s more than I deserve.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You owe her.

utterance.speaker: Hank
utterance.content: Everything.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So, the attempted suicide, the scaring her to death, that’s-what is that, that’s-gratitude? Love? Yeah, I get that. We’ll take out what you did to yourself yesterday, we’re back to the kidneys and the bones. I’m scheduling the transplant. NEVER visit a patient.

utterance.speaker: Hank
utterance.content: I want that baby! Even if I’m gone, that’s a piece of me, and Lola. Breathing. Walkin’ around town. Goin’ to baseball games. If there’s any more transplant talk from you, or Lola, or anybody else…I won’t screw it up this time. I’ll take myself out for good.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’ll start treating the Addison’s, which will most likely destroy what’s left of your kidneys-

utterance.speaker: Hank
utterance.content: Fine. Start the treatment.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Hey.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Hank Wiggen peed on me. What d’you think these pants are worth on eBay?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I’ve got some big-boy diapers in my office, the rep. hands them out like candy.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Is it that bad?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: No! Not if you like the smell of urine-

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: ‘Course, why should I trust someone who lies about what he’s doing Friday night? Question is, what are you really doing Friday night? Or more to the point, what could possibly be better than monster trucks? Or are we breaking up?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: …Stacy’s coming into town this weekend, we’re having dinner. Just…catching up.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I definitely had pants here. Wait a second, is that Stacy the Stripper? I heard she’s playing Atlantic City.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: No, Stacy the Constitutional Lawyer.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You thought I couldn’t handle this news. You talk to her a lot?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: No. It’s been a long time. If you don’t want me to see her-

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What is this, eighth grade? I’m fine.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: …It’s fine if you’re upset-

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No! It’s… I have no right to be upset. You two are friends. You should see her. Say hi for me.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: So…you’re okay.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m not the cancer doctor who’s lying about the cancer dinner. I’m not the one who’s betraying all those…bald-headed dying kids. I’m gonna go get some pants, I stink.

utterance.speaker: Lola
utterance.content: You’re treating him for Addison’s and you don’t think it’s gonna work?!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He tried to kill himself.

utterance.speaker: Lola
utterance.content: I know. He’s confused. We can have another baby, I can make him understand that. I’m having an abortion. We do the trans-

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Lola
utterance.content: I can make decisions about my body.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And he can make decisions about his. He doesn’t want your kidney.

utterance.speaker: Lola
utterance.content: So…he’ll die?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: …Probably.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If you keep that appointment, he’ll also probably die. Keep the baby.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: …Are you just being polite? See, my pants are…

utterance.speaker: Lola
utterance.content: Oh, they’re all wet.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: …You can’t smell that?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Think she’ll abort anyway, try to force his hand?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: No, she’s not gonna risk losing him.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: That’s funny?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: N-no, the monster trucks? House asking you, that’s…that’s funny.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I was the first person he ran into, he just…asked me.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Yeah, like a date!

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Exactly. Except for the “date” part.

utterance.speaker: Sharon
utterance.content: If the patient decides to go the dialysis route, we got some product you should check out. Hey, Dr. Foreman.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Courtesy of the generous Sharon and the good folks at Casting Pharmaceuticals.

utterance.speaker: Sharon
utterance.content: I was just telling the guys about the Bermuda conference in April.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Three days of sun and scuba, and one hour of lecture.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Oh God, do we have to go to the lecture?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So, you’re the new Arnie.

utterance.speaker: Sharon
utterance.content: Dr. House. It’s, uh, good to see you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Would you get me a coffee? Black, no sugar. Okay, so who is it? Come on, she’s sleeping with one of you. Oh God, please tell me it’s you.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: She buys lunches! She doesn’t-

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Don’t worry, you’re not gay…you’re adventurous!

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: You think she’s gonna prostitute herself? The three of us are that important to her?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m afraid not, no. The groupies sleep with the roadies in order to get to Mick.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: And…you’re Mick?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Why are you here?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I was just in Hank’s room, and he said it smelled like the men’s room at Veteran’s Stadium. He was right.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: We rejected environmental causes because the wife was healthy. Well, she’s not. Last six months, she can’t smell a thing. If you think of them as one single patient, add her symptoms to his…

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Cadmium poisoning.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It explains everything. Even why they had so much trouble getting pregnant.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: How could they have gotten exposed to that much cadmium?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Unless they were eating steel and batteries for breakfast.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So, where else is cadmium?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Some foods, polluted groundwater, we should check their home-

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I think I know how it happened.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I’m gonna need another urine sample.

utterance.speaker: Lola
utterance.content: What for-

utterance.speaker: Hank
utterance.content: Sure, whatever you want.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Why wouldn’t you give it to me before but now it’s no problem?

utterance.speaker: Hank
utterance.content: I’m dyin’, right?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: So you’ve got nothing to lose this time. Begs the question… what were you worried about last time? The funny thing is, when we tested you before, we were just looking for steroids. What should we look for now, Hank?

utterance.speaker: Lola
utterance.content: Hank? What’s the story?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: A little weed every now and then when no one was looking?

utterance.speaker: Lola
utterance.content: I don’t believe this. We quit.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: You did. If you’d kept going, you wouldn’t have just lost your sense of smell.

utterance.speaker: Hank
utterance.content: No, I quit the hard stuff. I just needed to relax.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Based on the symptoms, you’re a lot more than a social user.

utterance.speaker: Lola
utterance.content: So you’ve been lying to me all this time.

utterance.speaker: Hank
utterance.content: …I’m sorry.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: There must’ve been cadmium in the soil where the marijuana was grown. Some people get bone loss, kidney failure, some people’s testes shrink, and some people lose their sense of smell. We’ll start treating it right away. You should be fine by opening day. Baseball’s in the summer, right?

utterance.speaker: Lola
utterance.content: It didn’t hurt the baby, did it? The cadmium?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: If you’ve been clean, the baby should be fine.

utterance.speaker: Lola
utterance.content: Okay.

utterance.speaker: Hank
utterance.content: Please. I’ll stop everything, I’ll-I’ll go to meetings every day! Lola.

utterance.speaker: Lola
utterance.content: Twice a day.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: How’d the ballplayer doing?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Much better.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Too bad about his career.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What d’you mean?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Major League Baseball’s collective bargaining agreement requires medical reports on all treatment. Given Hank’s history he's not likely to get much leniency.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why should they care that he’s being treated for Addison’s?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You’re not treating him for Addison’s!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: My report says I am.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You’re lying on the report?!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Everybody does stupid things, it shouldn’t cost them everything they want in life.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: No, it shouldn’t, but it usually does. On the other hand, it means someone can actually beat the Yankees.

utterance.speaker: Sharon
utterance.content: So what about House, any way to get him down there?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You really wanna…talk about work?

utterance.speaker: Sharon
utterance.content: No. Not at all…

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: That was amazing!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m telling you, Gravedigger never disappoints.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You ever been married?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well now, let’s not ruin a lovely night out by getting personal.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I lived with someone for a while. You gonna finish that?
